SGJmAPCIB8w6BbtiAubdQg.text: I Grew up in Miami Florida Eating Cuban Food and this Establishment is a BLESSING for us South Florida / East Coast AZ Residents. I thank the food Gods for this place!   There is no bad food here but if your going for a first time i have some great suggestions- load up on the pastries! They are to die for and worth fattening up over - my fav is the Guava and Cream cheese yum.    If your going for lunch /dinner do not miss the classic cubano sandwich  - holy yummy! The pork is just like Miami pork and the pressed bread is amaze-balls! Also the meat pies are a NOT MISS!   They also serve classic cuban Breakfast and cafe con leche (cuban coffee and milk) the eggs are the best in town! And the classic coffee and milk is just a blast from the past from my Miami days!   In All obviously its a must try -  support this small business get out of your normal food box and discover your next Addiction

XEHDRHn7L5trMptVX4WtIw.text: Surprised my wife who had been bugging for authentic Cuban food. Yeah we use to go to Havanna Cafe,  Porto's and the long trip to Miami. Now I think I've lost her...Great Food...

nnT4wal6ejYAPr-bdNGC5Q.text: One of very few Cuban spots in Phoenix. I am a frequent customer here. My friends and I have tried a lot of the menu. Porks and steaks are great. Moros y Cristianos are great too. Having lived in Miami, this is not bad Cuban food considering we are in the desert.

T5FbBSmPTTcdLPvzm-v9kQ.text: I can't believe it took us so long to discover this authentic Cuban Restaurant. It's like we are back in Miami, where I grew up. OUTSTANDING!!!

nKkSa3iho1Lu1YDL5lUUSA.text: It's a shame this great tiny Cuban Place didn't remove the former Mexican Restaurant's sign with the name Bisteces. Also the old Mexican Food Bisteces Sign is still on one side of the shopping center too so if your looking for this place the Bisteces sign might still be up.   This very casual place is very tiny and only has 5 or 6 tables.  We started with the Papa Rellenas (fried mashed potatoes with a tangy seasoned beef center) I didn't know that they would be so large and the size of grapefruits since they were only $3.45 and they gave us two of them. This variation wasn't breaded and seemed lighter than others. The beef inside was very flavorful but not hot with spice.  I had the Pollo de la Plancha that is basically pounded chicken breast seasoned with lime  garlic and onions. The plate didn't look very attractive but the chicken was moist and very flavorful. They gave me an extra generous portion of rice with it and the plate was garnished with a light salad. ($6.99)  My companion had the Ropa Vieja. The beef was very flavorful but not hot with spice.  He found some bay leaves in his Rice and Beans. We've seen at some other Cuban Restaurants that when you find a bay leaf in your Rice and Beans it's like a prize and you get a free drink. I doubt they do that here as I didn't ask but it might be a fun thing to know. ($7.99)  The only thing I didn't like was if you need a restroom you have to walk threw a work area.  Someone from Yelp needs to remove the Mexican food reviews from Bisteces from this place.   I think the food from here will appeal to most people.

Ked_RF4odI2_C4jP2WN5aQ.text: I once had a friend who I would visit for business reasons several times a week. She lived in a beautiful house atop a mountain overlooking the ocean. She would start my day with a heart-starting cup of Cuban coffee, feed me sugar-laden Cuban pastries and at lunch drop me to my knees with the most incredible Cuban meals.  Maria moved back home to Miami and I visited her several times, including a memorable visit to a local Cuban district that tourists never see, where we wined and dined the night away as if in the golden days of Havana. I have tasted and appreciated REAL Cuban food and I know what it should be. Cuban Foods has brought it to Phoenix!  Today, on the way to pet sit for some friends and being a Sunday a favorite go-to little dive was closed and since I was looking at a bio of Mark Cuban (not a Cuban) I wondered if there were any good Cuban restaurants in Phoenix. What a surprise, there was one only a few blocks away from our friends' house.  We walked in, two guys, early on a Sunday afternoon. Every table was full; it seemed all with local Cuban families. We were approached and greeted by a young man who welcomed us, asked us if it was our first time there, and explained that they are a family restaurant. He mentioned that several times, with a lot of pride. Since the tables were full and we had the opportunity to take our order out and eat it at our friend's house while we pet sat, he was happy to accommodate.  I have been fortunate to have been welcomed at some of the most incredible small mom & pop dives in America by wonderful hosts, many times the owners or family, but I must say this young man ranks at the very top. He was literally glued to us to assure we received the absolute most personal and most welcoming service. After handing us the unbelievably complex menu he stuck close, helping us wade through it, and finally pointing out our best choice for a "to go" order, their Cuban Sandwich, and suggesting that it is so large that we could easily share it.  He then patiently explained their drink menu (non-alcoholic) that he proudly let us know was brought in from Miami. After taking care of our orders he noticed that there were not enough chairs for us to sit in while waiting for our take out so he graciously snagged another chair for us. Not that the order took that long to prepare. And GRACIOUS is the key word, this young man was gracious beyond belief.  The Cuban sandwich was, indeed, large. Much too large for one person to usually eat, so splitting it was an excellent idea. From my memories of what Maria used to prepare for me, this was 100% authentic Cuban, not that I had any doubts. The only, um, negative is that in our Styrofoam box in addition to the sandwich halves pierced by a single pimento-stuffed olive each was a handful, and I'm talking about a tiny handful, of limp cold French Fries. The fries were an embarrassment to the high quality of the sandwich. PLEASE, owners of Cuban Foods ... understand right now that the cold soggy fries are a huge negative. Replace them with something else, anything else! Some Cuban rice. Some Cuban beans. A slice of Plantain. Throw the fries in the trash and NEVER serve them again.  I will overlook the horrible choice of fries this one time and rank Cuban Foods as a solid 5, which it earned without question on the strength of the young man's astounding customer service and by virtue of a sandwich that surpassed all expectations. Listen up. Next time I visit I hope and expect never to find French Fries again in your amazing little restaurant! And I hope any restaurant worker in America, employee or family, can learn from this young man's amazing commitment to customer service.  I'm sure even Gordon Ramsey would approve!

2mTThc3fs7uWlQdA4109AA.text: Great food, fast service! Love this place. We originally came here for ropa vieja and ended up ordering a few things of of their menu--- all of which were delicious! FIVE STARS.

yW21s6GA2KCABcEVi6XpsA.text: Authentic Cuban food. Small local restaurant for intimate group. Lovely home made tasty dishes & friendly server.

GEu6bt-xFLOqgEm6C9r0yA.text: I'm rating at 3.5 stars, but don't have that option.  I went there never having had Cuban food before.  I had the pork and black bean rice.  As far as food goes, I liked it very much.  If I were to rate just the food, it would be 5 stars.  It was that good.  The service itself was also very good, and the server took good care of us.  No complaints there.    However there were two issues.  The first was not within the restaurant's control, so it was not their fault.  There was a large, noisy family that literally took up half the restaurant, which has a small eating area.  I would say at most it can seat 40 people, if that.  While this trashy, noisy family was not the fault of the restaurant, it sort of put a damper on a first time experience at this place, as well as a first time experiencing Cuban food.   The second issue was the dirty silverware.   The forks were poorly washed and had food particles on them. Since the server had their hands full with the obnoxious family, I didn't want to pile on with the silverware, and I just used a spoon instead, but I didn't like that.    My recommendation is the food is great, and the servers are nice, but just get the food to go.

lWDv9VsGuOFfiWa69deJ1w.text: I saw all the good reviews so had to check it out. Big portions, tasty.  -Tostones Rellenos de Jamon y Queso - 5 stars worth. So tasty and crunchy specially when it steaming hot -Sandwich Cubano - 3 star. The sandwich was good, but it was too dry for me. It was  really dry -Ropa Vieja - 5 star. This was really good. I ate the whole plate -Toscinillo del Cieli - 3 star. Decent, the cake was a bit on the soggy side.

rp-93SCSYUBvlecdeZ-VTw.text: Man, this is a tough review to write.  The food was great, but the service...ugh...we were there for almost two hours.  It was a full 40 minutes to get appetizers, an hour until we got food.  It was clear they were short-handed that day, but it was Saturday at lunch, the place is small.  How about planning?  Very disorganized service too, forgetting things and getting some wrong.  Everyone was friendly, just short-handed and disorganized.  I'll go again, as it's the only place I've found in the valley closer to me than Ahwatukee that serves honest and authentic Cuban food (being Cuban myself, I've had a sample or two of what it should be).  I'd recommend trying it.  Just plan to spend a lot of time there.

ymiE13mdPNDOw0GSlu7tuA.text: Let me start by saying that this is the first Cuban restaurant I have ever been too. Honestly I didn't know what to expect, since I never had Cuban food, only seen pictures. ..   For starters we had tostones De camaron, so good . Is garalic Shrimp and they provide enough for two. I will definitely be returning to eat them again.  I was so excited to try their Cuban sandwich.I was very excited because I am fan of the Cuban torta(mexican version) of their sandwich. To find out that there is so much difference from both. The sandwich has pork , ham , cheese, pickles , mayo and mustard. No veggies. I honestly am not used to eating a sandwich without veggies (next time I'll add lettuce and tomato ) and the sandwich is pretty big , especially after stuffing your face with appetizers !    their menu also has a item called Cuban sandwich (Mexican style) I believe they might be referring to the torta. Even tho they have different ingredients; I do not recommend, I also ordered it and is almost the same as the Cuban sandwich, but different bread and with lettuce ,which is not the definition for a Mexican torta.  The service was great , the person working there was so attentive, even tho she was the only one there talking care of 5 tables.   Before you leave I know you will be so stuffed and you are not going to be thinking of food anymore buuuut I recommended you try their bread, just take it home and eat it later. I honestly don't know the names of the bread but none disappointed me. Is so different from what I tend to eat, so I was glad I took some home.

Lak0L3fb3HXdlWJrBp6YBQ.text: Over all the best Cuban food you'll find in AZ. My husband and I have looked up and down for a good Cuban restaurant and had been unsuccessful until now. My husband had "the pollo a la Planca with arroz blanco, frijoles and maduros". I had the "busted empanizado con morros, ensalada y yuca." I was honestly very impressed. We had come to this restaurant a few years ago with my father in law and at the time it was much smaller and the quality of food lacked. We decided to give it another try and it was well worth it! So glad we came back! The food was delicious and the service was good. (Which is more than we expected) so glad we came!

aVoe9jTc2COwT6g7lnA71g.text: I lived for 30 years in south Florida, and after moving to Phoenix was thrilled to find a Cuban restaurant here. We miss boiled yucca, plantains, lechon asado, and especially cafe con leche.  Sadly, we were disappointed in this restaurant. The cafe con leche was merely instant coffee stirred into hot water, and the meal overall was mediocre. Based on the positive reviews here, we're willing to visit a second time - maybe for lunch, but our dinner here made us miss the wonderful Miami restaurants even more.

The flan was ok but nothing amazing. The only disappointment was they don't have standard Cuban items like "cheese rolls" which I'm used to finding in all the Cuban places in CA. Definitely worth a second visit.

8sE5m-dY9AW0JwErXXvuOA.text: One of my favorite spots to eat, and I will gladly drive the distance to get my fix! I went last night after not having gone for almost 9 months. Was pleasantly surprised to find they have either remodeled, or moved to the store next to the old one for a larger location, including (yay!) a bathroom, which the old location did not have! New location was larger, more open, clean, and nicely decorated. Our server was very nice and attentive, and service was fast as well. Ordered lechon asado and maduros, and it was enough for dinner, and lunch today. Can't wait to go back!

Jv5CdkT5jPUmSwlXxLUspw.text: I'll get right to it, this place gets 5 stars for serving the best Cuban food in the valley and three stars for comfort and service.  I love visiting ethnic places where the crowd is mostly natives. We came on a Sunday for lunch. Six of the six tables were occupied by Hispanics, three of which were Cuban families. As most reviewers note, the place is small, and had only one waitress/hostess/cashier/busgirl taking care of the entire place. We had to wait a bit but she was nice and attentive, but a bit overwhelmed. My three star rating is not because service was poor, they just need to hire one more person.  The food is very authentic. The tostones and platanos maduros were made fresh, the fries yuca was frozen but tasted good. The croquetas were also frozen but good as well. For entrees we had the masas de puerco and the ropa vieja, both authentic and tasty! It reminded me of a corner joint in Miami (except for the frozen products).  To the owners... great job! Consider expanding to achieve a 5 star review.

lTtsZzE36Kpb-S5kMo299w.text: I have been missing my dad's cooking and found out about this place. All the positive reviews won me over.  My wife and I tried to have dinner here.  When we entered there were 2 employees working.  They both looked over at us but didn't say anything.  So we assumed that meant we seat ourselves and someone would be with us.  As we tried to fi d a table to sit at we would every table we looked at was dirty.  One of the 2 employees finally came over and cleaned off a table for us. He gave us menus and said someone would be right with us.  We waited and waited.  Both he and the other employee looked directly at us but made no move to help us.  Then a small party came in.  They were helped Immediately. That was my limit.  We got up and walked out never having anyone take our orders.  This was so disappointing.  I don't know if we just caught them on an off night or what but the complete lack of service was ridiculous.

l4Y_evuusoIwBxSqQCooww.text: I'm not Cuban. I've never been to Miami so take this review however you like, but the Cuban sandwich here is DELICIOUS. It's huge and has everything a Cuban sandwich is supposed to have, roasted pork, ham, swiss, pickles, yellow mustard, delicious bread. Great job!

8XXVj9bjtHfsg7DSskHQSg.text: Wanted to love, but couldn't. I've got a pretty open palate and not that this is what I consider adventurous, I am not afraid to try almost anything. After reading the reviews I HAD to try this. When I'm trying a type of food I have a tendency to try a lot just in case I will never be back. I'm not judging service because I realize there is one super sweet lady working up front, and she was nice. Aside from food, the only thing is this is really small, which is great, but when people come in, I started to feel obligated to hurry and finish so there was space for them. Anyway. Food ordered as followed: papa rellenas- meh. Good, my husband liked more than I did, but seemed to be lacking flavor. I loaded mine with Tapatio, but the meat filling just didn't have much discernable anything. Tostones was next and it seemed mismatched. Vastly improved with tapatio. Also got the cubano sandwich, which was good, the bread was perfect actually, however it had some insanely hard parts that I literally couldn't chew up. Like bone fragments, but they weren't, just crazy hard meat. Flavor wise very good. I think the lady dish we got was the beef bistec, which was dry and flavorless. The onions were the only thing that saved it to keep it edible. Ordered some desserts as well, but not impressed there either. I might have a screwed perception of flan, bit I expected it to be creamier.  Overall nothing was horrible, but nothing was magical.  Super bummed.

iwti0cHg25bQqk-Z9eqwsw.text: Croquettes de Jamon were delicious; as was the Cuban coffee.  Small, unassuming restaurant tucked away in a strip mall serving authentic, tasty Cuban food....would stack up with mom and pop places in Miami!  I'm glad I stumbled across this place.

GBE0khsw9Kq39-REc4_2mA.text: This is one of those little gems waiting to be diacovered, after visiting it a few times this is now my favorite restaurant in phoenix . I am from Puerto Rico and it is hard  to get good  Caribbean food in phoenix, therefore I fell in love with this place after coming here (by way of yelp). The food in Bisteces feels authentic with the right seasoning and preparation. I have tried other places around the area and they are descent but nothing compares to this.I would recommend trying the bistec uruguayo, it is very tasty.

CseRdeweUvPT7jHsFeV71A.text: Best Mexican food I've had in a while. I just wish their tortas were bigger.

D6r5gXaCVAUUcQYkdRpesQ.text: Everything was great, the only reason I gave it a four stars instead of five stars was some of the food were a little too salty, particularly the pork tamale and bistec urguaueno. My friend, a Miami cuban, had the bistec en cebolla and said it was well seasoned, not salty, and it reminded her of her grandmother's cooking. The blackbeans were awesome and the flan was perfect.

oTlPIoUQbjS8EiqPNWIQrA.text: Came for lunch on a Yelp recommendation. Had a Cuban sandwich to go and it was amazing! I ate half and was taking a break when my wife came home for lunch and took the rest. Great flavor, temperature, and texture. This restaurant is 20 minutes from home and I will definitely be back for eat-in - and to try the baked goods!

4bEJYChMCtszMyLxhDfnWw.text: The Cuban sandwich was very good, and it's a pretty large portion. It can easily be split between two people. The flan was delicious. The consistency of the flan is more porous and firm than some of the most common Mexican types. We also had the guava pastry, which was great. Looking forward to eating here again!

w549lHaYAX_bVnEa8bR65Q.text: Unpretentious, inexpensive, authentic and a trip to hometown down flavor-town-road  waiting to happen.  Born in Puerto Rico and a traveler by choice, I'm always searching for that special gem hidden amongst all the noise other have to make.  Cuban Foods is by far the best cuban restaurant in the valley.  The menu is simple while including all the treats one expects for an establishment of its kind.  "El Congri", "los tostones", ""el pernil asado", sandwich "cubano", "la media noche", "el flan", are a few of the delicious item that will entice your taste buds.  All they are missing is the sound of the Caribbean waves breaking against "El Malecon", the smell of the ocean in the air and the palms trees, as if dancing, swaying at the rhythm of the sea winds.  Oh yes, the staff can accommodate our spanish challenged brothers and sister without missing a beat.  Do not be afraid and take this free trip to Havana, any time.

UV0_SlnY_aOWtiEIvRHrvQ.text: This is the best hole-in-the-wall Mexican establishment I have found in Arizona. With Mexican food I generally believe that there is an inverse relationship between taste and price, Bisteces is an excellent example of this phenomenon. Bisteces serves yummy authentic Mexican food in a cute environment with hand painted walls. I will also say that the bathroom is one of the cleanest public restrooms I have visited. Although probably not worth a long drive, I will definitely return to Bisteces.

I also got a super fresh, super delicious horchata. And the man who took my order (I'm pretty sure it's the owner) topped it off. (That's awesome!)  The place was VERY clean, quite a few booths available, had a TV. Anyway, I loved it and I'll be going back again for sure.

khAD9_Y2-5lDdS05NTeWfg.text: This place is definitely authentic Cuban cuisine.  We ordered the Cuban sandwich and tostones (fried green plantains).  The food was delicious!  As another reviewer stated, the bread was a bit crumbly.  I grew up in Florida, so I have had plenty of Cuban sandwiches in my lifetime, so I know that the bread is supposed to be somewhat crumbly, but it was a little over the top.  Also, it was a to go order, and it took about 30 minutes for us to get our food.  Slow, but worth it in my opinion.  Next time we will just call ahead.  My husband made a comment about the cashier/waitress's personality (or lack thereof), but I didn't really notice anything.  She was really busy though, being the only one who was taking orders, cashing out customers, bringing out the food and cleaning the tables.  I would be miserable too, poor girl!  Anyway, the crumbly bread and slow service are what made me take away a star.  However, we will definitely be back.  It's hard to find Caribbean cuisine in the valley, especially as good as this!

27nlTQ5gh66KaooCD-MByg.text: This place is legit! The foods is oh so flavorful without being too salty. Portions aren't  over done...but its filling and satisfying. Being from Puerto Rican heritage...this place brings me back to my moms home cooking with a different flare. Will definitely come back and try other things on the menu. We loved the Yucca frita and Tostones Rellenos de Camaron (root veggie stuffed with garlic shrimp). Their mojo is garlicky and to die for. xu8dBCjMmiOXBgIleA4a4w.text: One of my favorite lunch spots.  The beef or pork specials on the lunch menu are both excellent, the Cuban sandwich is also great.  Good with a side of fried sweet plantains!!!

Ru1XkL3kqnTU4KVCHB7A0Q.text: Que Rico! Brush up on your spanish, because the real Cuban foodies know where to come! This little hole in the wall Cuban restaurant is seriously as authentic as it gets.  I grew up in Puerto Rico, and  I'm telling you, this food is like no other.  Don't try to compare it to the likes of Havana Cafe in Phoenix . This super casual, obscure 5 or 6 table Cuban Cafe and Bakery, is tucked away in a strip mall.     Please believe me, they serve THE best tostones, croquetas de jamon, pan con bistec, ropa vieja, empanada de carne and crazy delicious flan. I'm sure everything else is tasty too, but I get stuck on my faves. This probably doesn't mean a lot to some, but they serve coca cola in tall glass bottles. This is the way the serve it in Mexico, Puerto Rico and Cuba. It just tastes so much better and it goes great with a cubano (cuban sandwich).   There is usually one girl serving the tables, and working the bakery, the owner and one or two other people in the kitchen...so service isn't what you would expect at a 5 star restaurant, but it is what you would expect at a Cuban neighbors or friends house, and that is exactly what you get.  And if you venture into this cafe a few times, the people working there will remember you and you will automatically feel like family.    Prices are great, portions are good and the food is excellent!  Buen Provecho!

QZPw9o_QgUDbgYT2vm0p-A.text: Before stopping in, I read the reviews and was a little concerned about the comments regarding the bread in the Cuban sandwiches being dry.  However, please remember, these are not French dips, this is exactly how they are supposed be.  The outside it toasted lightly and is supposed to be a little dry with the mustard moistening it up inside.  The fried plantains were amazing, the mashed potato fried appetizer things were amazing, the black beans, and rice, sandwiches, all were absolutely authentic.  But the best part, yes, the fat man knows, the best part was the flan over cake desert.  Oh my lord, that was a great way to end the meal.  Overall, I'm from Florida where Cuban restaurants are all over the place and this is as good or better than I have ever had.  Great job.

5JMGroHcxOCqgU_JYGIhWA.text: I'm  always  in search of good Cuban  restaurants., found this one on yelp.  We came in for lunch,  the place is small inside but luckily  we found a table.   I ordered  the Cuban sandwich with a side of black beans cooked with the rice.  The first thing I noticed was the bread was the right bread for the sandwich. Not just a friendly roll.  I asked and they bake their own bread.  The sandwich  was excellent  and rivaled any you would buy in Miami.  I also ordered  papas  rellena  which is a ball of mashed potatoes stuffed with ground beef then lights breaded and deep fried.  Great flavor. I ordered a guava  pastry to see how they did.  Also excellent.  I was not disappointed.   Looking through  the menu they had all the typical Cuban dishes and the prices were fair.  Average  dinner plate was $9-$10.  Just a note- my buddy ordered the Mexican style Cuban  torta (can't remember  the name of the sandwich) .  I tasted it and it was epic.  Such great  flavor.  It had pork,  onions,  cheese and other things that gave it a little kick but not too spicey. Look for it on the menu,  you will love it.   Hot tip- seating is minimal,  get there before lunch or dinner rush.  I got there about  11:30 and it wasn't  busy.  By 12:30 people  were waiting for tables.   All in all great food,  the owners were Cuban  and know their stuff!

6W4Vgu1m80HJbk97CvGzpA.text: Went in for lunch not long after they opened yesterday and the place was pretty much deserted. We were seated immediately and given menus. There is a lot on the menu that looks good and pretty much everything in the small bakery case at the front looks amazing. Ordered the ham croquettes and a cuban sandwich. The croquettes were pretty meh. It tasted like a deep fried wad of dough with little else going for it. The sandwich was really good and enormous. I ended up eating half and tapping out. The fries were a little too fried for me to the point they were almost like potato chips. Also, whatever tap they're getting their water from needs a filter or something. I sipped my water sparingly because the taste is just bad. Ended up tasting a bit of the chocolate eclair and it was as good as it looked. Going through their dessert case would probably be a blast until your pancreas gave out.   Definitely would go back for the sandwich and baked goods.

PoITnoOYz9TUKX7XJMSXXQ.text: Tried this place for the first time. I ordered the Cubano Sandwich and it was hands down the best Cuban sandwich I've ever had. The portion was huge making this an easily shareable sandwich. The bread they used was crispy and flaky and oh so yummy!! The pork was flavorful and tender. The fact that this was a shareable sandwich was good because that left room for dessert, and their flaky pastries or fluffy cakes would make it a sin to leave without having some. I had a flaky pastry reminiscent of an enormous cream puff with delicious vanilla pudding in it and strawberry sauce and powdered sugar drizzled on top. I will definitely be back!!

UdD5N1tqXsBo02TzpkTyPg.text: We have been on the lookout for a Cuban restaurant as our beloved CA Cuban jem Porto's is no longer an option unless we want to drive 6 hours for some croquettes. This place was perfect, and the next best thing. We went Saturday for lunch and were promptly greeted and seated ourselves. They arrived to our table promptly with menus and we received our appetizers in a short time. They timed everything perfectly as we just finished our empanadas and our main dishes arrived.....so DELICIOUS!!! The Cuban sandwich was a generous portion and the tops vieja was more than enough. We both had to take half home because we got too full from the appetizers, so worth it though. The flavors of everything we ate were perfect! We will definitely be going back soon when in the area. It's a mini mission to go there as we live I  Surprise, but I'm sure we'll be back soon!! Thank you for the great service and amazing food!!!

RcRICUFyMFbDx_d-LzAEaw.text: There aren't many Cuban restaurants in Phoenix so this is always a nice treat for some Cuban food. Staff is very friendly but it can take a bit...

rfHh4fpESv1wVwrn5SrYcQ.text: Before stopping in, I read the reviews and was a little concerned about the comments regarding the bread in the Cuban sandwiches being dry.  However, please remember, these are not French dips, this is exactly how they are supposed be.  The outside it toasted lightly and is supposed to be a little dry with the mustard moistening it up inside.  The fried plantains were amazing, the mashed potato fried appetizer things were amazing, the black beans, and rice, sandwiches, all were absolutely authentic.  But the best part, yes, the fat man knows, the best part was the flan over cake desert.  Oh my lord, that was a great way to end the meal.  Overall, I'm from Florida where Cuban restaurants are all over the place and this is as good or better than I have ever had.  Great job.

OB61n_MtcjFFVxJl2tj4IQ.text: Super small restaurant tucked into a shopping plaza - but trust me you'll want to pop in to this gem.  The seating area is super small (and there are no restrooms for public use). The tables are set with baskets of napkins and straws, hot sauce and s/p. The service is friendly and fast. This place was packed during our visit but they made sure to check in and attend to everyone.   We ordered the cubano sandwich, bisteak dinner with rice, and empanadas and cheese rolls for appetizers. Holy cow! Everything was super hot, tasty, and came in big portions! Definitely bring your appetites! We like to try new places and we're so happy we found this one! We'll be back again!

sp7LVhGpxgh9JMss-0DufA.text: I am from the NYC area where Cuban food is excellent everywhere in the NYC/NJ area. My husband and I ate at this restaurant for the first time a few days ago and the food was the absolute worst I've had. The customer service there was awful, their steak was dry and burnt, their Cuban rice and beans were obviously not fresh and their Cuban Potato was mediocre. My husband had to send his steak back and they argued that the steak is supposed to be like this. After everything was said and done we paid $50 for crappy good. Never again will we eat there.

yG1yWvaSTASxXsXvLlFlnQ.text: I went to this restaurant with a group of 20 plus that I was hosting.  Lester and Yoetni, did such an excellent job in serving us as well as taking care of all other customers.  There was more than 20 checks between our group.  The food was outstanding and provided such a great taste of Cuban culture.  The two gents attitude was amazing and I would very much go here again!

xEaCccRUw_RZ9SD7ujR5nw.text: This was such a find! Brought my parents that recently moved here from Puerto Rico after hurricane Maria. You should have seen the the smiles on their faces as they listened to salsa music and enjoyed the beautiful pictures of the Caribbean. And the food! Excellent. Ropa Vieja was insane.  The rice, beans and flan were excellent. And the server was so sweet. Be patient if you're hungry but it's worth the wait. Can't wait to go back!

UryuuR_QLD72vIPE-N586w.text: Came in on a Saturday around 5:30pm, and ordered a media noche and the papa rellenas to-go. Restaurant was empty except for one table. What put us off was that we waited almost 45 minutes for our food. 45 minutes for a sandwich!?   Food: the sandwich was good, could have used more pickles to balance it out. The potato balls were amazing! Service: Despite not being busy, we sat there and waited for 30 minutes before we had to go up to the counter to ask about our food. After saying she would check on the food, no one followed up with us. We sat there for another 10 minutes before a waiter told us we would have to wait another 7-8 minutes. We would have understood if they had forgot -- we get and respect that things happen. But when we asked if there was a problem, all he said was "nope." If you make a mistake, at least be honest.

NhUiBU_xF82bNR_JuyEgrA.text: Had a medianoche sandwich, yucca, and a flan topped cake and they were excellent. The front house were nice but it was disorganized and chaotic even though it was not busy or crowded.

-4H81behc2p0qTemaq9Lhg.text: If you want happy hour be sure to ask for seating either at the bar or at the high tops.  The decor is pleasing. Presentations of the food are great.  Fried plantains are awesome.  Out of what we had I would recommend a sampler to try and find what you like the most.  I like a little bit of everything first time to target what I like most when trying a new cuisine.

Kn_dYiAYy61PIgPs_wO5xw.text: This place is awesome! When the food overflows the plate, it is authentic. I ordered the Cuban sandwich which was excellent and we took home 2 bags of crackers and flan home!

Ik6rXPcdHXLyHnJYIMqbLA.text: I cannot explain the pastry here.  The guava pastry is insane.   That with a side of black beans, and varied plantains, I'm in love.  I'm a vegetarian, so there were not many options for me.  I would have loves a veggie type version of the empenadas , but the food was great anyway!  I plan on returning in the morning to see the full selections.

3T-0wSE07yTDioI5dUHx5g.text: The sandwiches here are AMAZING.  I've had Cuban sandwich before, but these guys step it up. The prices are pretty low for w what you get, and the quality is great.

The hubby and I order it with extra pickles because, why not? It's big enough to share but we still order two and have leftovers. t3TMJOpcDEV96C3llTLelw.text: Oh my belly....I'm never going to stop eating pork. Never! The lechon asado (roast pork) is amazing! I even ate the onions and so did my sister! Don't forget the black beans. I couldn't stop eating!! I really need to forget about this restaurant before I become plus size ( not that there's anything wrong with that but my knees will hate me). Back to the pork: you are served more than four ounces but I'm sure you won't mind once your taste buds are introduced to the great flavor. What's that delectable seasoning on it Mr. Chef??? Next time sis and I will sneak into the kitchen to watch the process moo ha ha! Oh yeah-- the guava con leche drink-- get it! I'm glad I don't have to return to Tampa for good Cuban food!

JW177TZJzEm2x8-pvQXAhQ.text: Loved the food! Took our kids in and we feasted on some sandwiches, fried mashed potatoes (with meat filling) and took home some amazing desert. The decor is nothing special but the food makes up for it.  We will be back!

c0lNqI59poGmFJbiuRsjHw.text: This is a fantastic restaurant located in the strip mall on the Northeast corner of 43rd Ave & Peoria.  The sign out front still reads "Bisteces" but there is also a sign featuring Cuba.  If you see either, you're in the right place.  I popped in around 11am and had my pick of any table in the house.  Be warned it is very small.  Drop in around dinner time and you may have to wait.  If so, it will be worth it.  The menu had a lot of options from sandwiches to meals.  After reading over the entire menu I opted for the Cuban sandwich.  I've heard many great things about the Cuban sandwich but had never had the luxury of eating one.  Elected for a side of seasoned rice & black beans as well.  The sandwich has huge.  The grilled bread was stuffed with ham, shredded pork, mustard and pickle.  While stuffed on sandwich and rice I managed to save a little room for a guava tart.  They had a few desert options in the case and this one looked the most enticing to me.  It was a worthy selection and completed the meal perfectly.   Cuban Foods also offers a variety of Cuban soft drinks as well as American restaurant standards.  I walked away with a can of sugared water called Ironbeer.  It had a unique flavor that I cannot describe but the can boasts it includes "island spice".  It was not something I would drink on a regular basis but worth checking out for something new.    Cuban Foods Bakery & Restaurant is a great dining option.  It's even worth the drive if a bit of a long haul.  Definitely give this place a shot.

htQQX-zkrj-N--qnnpOOYg.text: I love this place pollo a la plancha delicious ! I think I'll stop by tomorrow again ! Me and my bro love this place The best lemonade I've ever had

KSLbAzGm1xt0wc4ppgtJOg.text: I have been looking for a Cuban Sandwich for a long time. I Googled Cuban Restaurants  I came across this place. I decided to try it. The ladies behind the counter and her cook are very nice and polite not to mention very good looking. I finally got to have my Cuban Sandwich. It was fantastic and big. I was only able to eat half of it.   I will definitely be going back there again not cuz of the ladies but cuz of their food. I I would like to explore more into Cuban Food and this is where I will be doing my exploring until I find another Cuban Bakery.  Do stop in and give it a try.

agpkpfYvnBMOpwCA--ce7Q.text: Omg! 37 minute drive was sooo worth it. As I've complained before, I'm a "starving for good food ny transplant" and this is crazy awesome the "real deal Cuban food". I ordered one of everything I miss from Leo's mom's cooking and took it home (7 dishes for $81...pretty good). Everything was cooked to order and if your not sure what to order, ask for a recommendation...they are happy to help. I never give 5 stars but I'm about the food and the service-this experience reminded me of eating at your best friend's house- small, intimate, friendly and food you don't get unless mom is in the kitchen. Viva la Cuba.

4U3qx8EKZYOYWxJEIV8WWA.text: Super yummy, authentic Cuban food. I got the yucca con mojo and the ropa vieja -- neither disappointed. Also tried a few desserts and those were pretty amazing as well!! iI6yA-RRHbemmqcypD4ZTg.text: Friendly, very tasty, Cuban food.  We will definitely be back to try the other dishes.  On this trip we had the "Ropa Vieja" and the "Bistec Uruguayo". W_IR9oNZSVOeYmBTOJ-vJA.text: My wife and I went here last week. When we pulled up we were kind of tentative given where it's at and how SMALL it is. My wife is a trained chef and we have eaten/lived from the California Wine country to Atlanta GA eating at some of the smallest backwoods hidden places to the biggest best restaurants.  This is one of those prized gems hidden in the weeds!  Looks can be deceiving and in this case that is most certainly True. I ordered the Cuban sandwich and an appetizer of plantain cups with shredded beef in them and my wife had a beef platter. Can't say enough good things about the service,food and pricing. I got the lunch sandwich which is supposed to be smaller but still took half home. I'd hate to see the regular portion!  We will certainly return to try the other dishes soon.

Cu9AtlCAPek0PcGhFmbSTg.text: Cuban Sandwich was great! Just like I've had in Miami. We also ordered flan which was good and some pastries which were fresh and yummy.

inQyg7SNe5uWv9VBIqhRbw.text: So good! I wish we lived closer.  Roast pork with onions, plantains, and black beans and rice.  All were amazing. Huge cuban sandwiches too.

WXgy69mToeImK9oFWf19Eg.text: When I lived in northwest Phoenix this restaurant was a favorite of mine. I wasn't able to patronize it much when I moved farther away but after a long hiatus I was able to try it again with my friend and fellow yelper John M. I was glad to see that they have expanded the restaurant, so the seating issue from past years has been resolved. We ordered croquetas de jamon which turned out to be a good choice for starters - a crisp exterior covers a tender and tasty mashed potato and ham interior. For my entree, I ordered my old favorite, ropa vieja. The braised shredded beef came with the requisite Cuban rice and a side salad; tasty and very satisfying, although compared to how it used to taste when I frequently ordered this a few years ago, it seems they have toned down the seasoning of the beef a tad. For dessert I had the tocinillo se cielo (literally, heaven's little pig or heaven's bacon), a heavenly concoction of flan layered on top of cake. Prices were good and service was friendly, and fast - I'm glad for that, because during the times I dined here in the past it took quite a while to be served and for the food to arrive; I'm glad all that has changed now.

mWqa92oZl7a3E_inxwwA-A.text: We love this place!! The staff is always helpful & friendly. We are vegetarian so we get beans & rice, yucca con mojo (soooo amazing! Garlic buttery goodness!), yucca fritas (crispy perfection!), any of the plantains are a great choice as well (from sweet to savory they are so yummy!)  My granddaughter (not a vegetarian) also loves the above & their papas rellenos (balls of mashed potato with a meat center. She tried the tamales for the first time & it was a hit.  Don't even think of going there without getting the flan! Get it to go if you are full (you Definately will be). Hubby & granddaughter veeredfrom the usual flan & trien a cream hirn & a cream puff. nIoa4iEgZEjj5J3IL19eXw.text: My husband was looking for Cuban coffee and we thought we finally found it, but I was just normal espresso. We got Cuban sandwich the portion was big and taste good. When I go to ethnic restaurant I'd like to see something different and I didn't get that, but food was good. Good for 1 time try but don't expect something special.

2Kkz4YFGWL4E-qQQ_kvjTg.text: Grew up on the West Coast, never had Cuban food, but my transplant friends from NY and Miami always went on about how they missed it. FFW to when I moved to DC, we found an excellent Cuban place and our attitude was "How had we not had this before!"  Well, now, having moved to AZ, in the back of my head, I thought I had surrendered the opportunity to bite into the flat crust of a pressed Cubano, or get ropa viejo stuck in my teeth, or gaze upon what seems like miles of a perfectly golden, crispy breaded protein. Say it ain't so!  Enter Cuban Foods and Bakery! We had the Bistec Uraguayo and the Bistec Encebollado, with a side of yucca and crispy plantains. The grilled steak and onions perfectly tender with the subtle spice and sweetness of the onions a well-matched compliment, the breaded pork steak with cheese and ham juicy, crunchy, gooey all at once. The Tostones, smashed fried plantains with garlic sauce, crispy like a potato chip, and the yucca flaky like a baked potato. Accompanied by Cristanos y Moros, presumably church-going white rice and mosque-attending black beans (though cooked in pork, not exactly the most devout of Muslim beans) all mixed together in perfect harmony - the world could maybe learn a bit from Cuban side dishes!   The tale of how we were happily reacquainted with an East Coast fave right off hwy 17 in Phoenix, Arizona - shout-out to Cuban Foods and Bakery!

rUyeA-1LeM8gfoY8vrclzQ.text: I've been looking for a Cuban sandwich place in Phoenix FOREVER. I came across this randomly on YELP yesterday and the craving got to me.  So, we headed down the way (not really too far from our house). It was about 6pm and the place had just a few people, the crowd growing as we ate and the phone seemingly always ringing with to-go orders. Got my Cuban and the lady got a steak variation of it (can't remember what it was called). She substituted her fries with black beans and rice (which was "okay"), I subbed mine with straight black beans (which were delicious), no problem for the waitress or the kitchen.   I ordered a Mexican Coke (which turned out to be the half-liter bottle not the 16oz) and came with a "rocks glass" filled with ice. Nice touch. Athena got a lemonade which fascinated her because it is kind of frozen like a slushie but with spherical ice balls that defy description. It's cold - don't freeze your esophagus by trying to suck it down! We also ordered Cuban coffee and the waitress asked if we wanted that before/with/after the meal and we voted after - possibly with something from the bakery case.  After we finished 1/2 of our sandwiches (THEY ARE BIGLY. TREMENDOUS. BELIEVE ME) and sides, another waiter asked if we needed a box and anything else - we got some sort of raspberry gel topped cream puff thing filled with a custard that was apparently delightful (I didn't partake) and he made sure we understood that the coffee was strong and came in tiny cups - hell yes - we get that, bring it on...we may just not sleep tonight!  We're going to finish it up tonight for dinner and then start planning our attack on broadening our horizons and branching out from the sanwich portion of the menu. I'll report back when we do. Oh, and I THINK I spotted a couple of kinds of beer in the fridge, but it's not on the menu.

sT8XhzgRSAoPVDnGL7NjJg.text: Friendly staff. The let down for me and my Cuban mother was the food. It did not taste authentic. She did not like any of the sandwiches we ordered mainly because of the type of bread that was used and the fries that come with them were hard.  The croqueta de jamon was not good at all. Definitely do not taste like ham and are more like fried dough. It is brown and mushy inside. My favorite dish was the Papa rellena, however my mother thought they had a strong cumin taste to them. In short, if you are looking for authentic Cuban food to reminisce on your childhood or even a visit from Cuba or Florida, this is not the place for it.

Ppjovf82lahVYjydoCJxog.text: Let me preface this by saying I am Cuban-American. While I haven't eaten food from the island itself, I grew up in Miami and had the second best thing for most of my life.  That said, I think the food was good and authentic. Many times people say their restaurant is Cuban, but it's not. THIS ONE is. Their flan is excellent (I don't even eat it that often, but my husband and I loved it).   I will say I find it a bit expensive BUT I also grew up having Cuban food on every corner, so it may just be a supply/demand kind of thing. Either way, whenever we are craving Cuban food, we will make the 30+ minute drive up here to order from them.  And if you've never had Cuban food before, THIS is the place to try it.

M-qev_AHMKqTiiGq7S3jQQ.text: This place dishes up some amazing Cuban food! It's tucked in the corner of a strip mall/ shopping area. I've tried several of their Cuban sandwiches, all delicious!! I'm looking forward to trying their paella and other dishes. Their pastries are really good, too. Not overly sweet. My only gripe is one time I ordered 2 breakfasts to-go... very small portions and it was $22 total. A little pricey for such skimpy meals. I should add that the breakfasts were more American-style dishes, bacon and eggs and scrambled eggs with ham. Both came with a piece of bread. That been said, I'll continue to try the Cuban food on their menu because they do it right!

15g3TIGwxi8At8fVY6FZBQ.text: Friendly staff, food is tasty, and definitely leave room for dessert!!   We will be coming back here for sure. Located behind the jack in the box, this place is worth stopping in and grabbing something to eat. The bakery is amazing!

SPlNHmLP6xnih0S7DYrE5Q.text: Oh man... I am disappointed that this place did not live up to what I had expected.   This place is tiny and it was packed On a Saturday at 2:30 PM. So we got 2 Cuban Sandwiches to-go, as well as some beef stuffed Plantains. The Plantains were way over cooked and had little to no flavor. The beef was pretty good, flavorful, and juicy. The Cuban Sandwich was pretty good. Needed a few more pickles and mustard. It just wasn't as amazing as I had pictured in my head. They were giant. definitely sharing status. The French Fries were... well French Fries.   I do want to give this place one more try. I am hoping they were just having an off day.

gW6j5gfuffoMfQU4frLb7A.text: Very tasty, unassuming little restaurant serving delicious Cuban fare. f you are craving a Cuban sandwich, trust me on the fact that one order will be plenty for two. My friend and I were both stunned at the sight of the gigantic appetizer...We ended up splitting a half as we did not want it to spoil our appetite for the tasty Cubano paninis...  ...Last but not least, make sure you try one of the delightful postres (desserts) and in this case we had flan...All that food for fifteen bucks...so glad we split a Cuban sandwiich as sincerely one order s plentiful for two. Glad to have stumbled upon this place - just really surprised that they were not busier at lunchtime on a Friday.  According to the menu, the restaurant also serves breakfast.  Wishing you much success!

pY7FWE-uaNhduMZC_yCVKA.text: Decided to give this place a go after my former Cuban haunt finally closed up their last location, and I had a lingering craving for some plantains.   Executive summary: I'm not sure I understand all the rave reviews for this place, and that's coming from someone that really likes Cuban food and wanted, very badly, to like this place.   When we arrived, the place was empty and the chef and the one (and only) server were basically just waiting for someone to stop in. I was surprised, given the glowing reviews and the fact that it was prime time for dinner, that nobody was there. I had been expecting a wait and was even worried that since it was a small place, we wouldn't be able to dine in.   We got seated right away and got menus pretty quick. Drink orders were not taken for some time, which I found strange considering, again, the place was absolutely deserted. I'm not a demanding customer, quite the opposite, but is it beyond the realm of possibility to get prompt drink service when you are literally the only customers in the establishment? Even after we ordered drinks, they did not come out quickly, which was just... awkward.  In terms of food, we tried a few things, starting with the appetizers. We had the ham croquettes and a side order of plantains. While the plantains were fantastic and every bit as good as I had hoped from my experience at other Cuban restaurants, the croquettes were a bit of a let down. They tasted nothing like ham and, to be honest, I wondered if we'd somehow gotten the wrong thing. In all honesty, the taste reminded me of a black bean fritter, but the receipt confirmed it was in fact the ham croquettes. Not sure what else to say expect I didn't really wouldn't know it was ham unless you told me.  Entrees were a step above the appetizers, which was good. My wife got the pollo ala plancha while I ordered the Cuban sandwich. Both were good, but I don't think either would qualify as great. The sandwich bread was a tad stale on the outside, which made for a very messy experience eating it, not to mention the fact that when your drink runs dry (which it did), it only exacerbates the situation (imagine eating a sandwich covered in saw dust, if you want a visual). The meat, cheese and mustard in the sandwich itself was great, don't get me wrong, and I would definitely eat it again, but not on this bread. It would have been easily twice as good an experience if the bread was a little fresher (or, put another way, less stale). Again, loved the flavors, and the portion size was massive, but bread makes or breaks any sandwich and took away from this one. The sandwich comes with fries, but they were nothing special and I agree with another reviewer, the quality of the fries takes away from the meal. I would suggest swapping them out with something more authentic, or at the very least, getting better fries. My wife's chicken dish was good, well seasoned and delicious, so there were no complaints there. So I guess to sum up, on balance, the entrees were good and I'd almost certainly give them another try.  The last thing I want to mention is the ambiance here. When the place is empty, it has a strange, almost cavernous acoustic echo going on, which is a little odd. It's one of those deals where you almost feel like you have to whisper because you can hear a pin drop and you feel like you're being too loud. If there were more people in there it might be different, but I can only speak for the experience that we had.   At the end of the day, I would probably give this place another try in the future, but with revised expectations, both regarding the food and service. I've no doubt the food is authentic enough for purists, but the little things do matter and they add up and on this visit the sum total was still shy of what I had hoped for. Hopefully subsequent visits will give me a reason to add a few stars. Definitely worth trying if you haven't been, but based on my visit, I don't understand all the hype.

57U-IRoOv_fXhuQqlrHw8w.text: Muy Bien Cuban Foods Bakery and Restaurant!!!    My daughter had a country project to work on for school and she had to bring in food representing the country.  We went down to Cuban Bakery and met with the owner.  He was sweet enough to provide us with a variety of samples for us to select.   We settled on Pastelitos.   I needed the Pastelitos early on a Tuesday morning.  The owner came into the bakery   extra early that day to bake and prepare.    7:00 that morning he was there with five boxes of fresh made Pastelitos which smelled and looked delicious.   The Pastelitos where a huge hit at the country   fair.  And I can't wait to go back and try a Cuban sandwich.   I appreciate that Cuban Foods and Bakery went above and beyond to help out.    If you have a chance stop by for a bite and support a local restaurant.

UUMEi6hOYXKNDZqJlOVsBg.text: I am in the future trip planning mode, and I need some relevant and current advice from friends that travel constantly.  We opted to meet up one Friday, just so that I could quiz them on travel trips to Europe and Asia, since I don't travel as much as I used to.  Since I was paying (as I always do!), I chose the venue. Cuban was agreed upon, and since we didn't really want to drive to downtown Mesa, we chose to meet up at this particular establishment.  Cuban foods is a full fledged bakery and a restaurant. It's filled with some great and delectable treats. Perhaps, not on par as one would sample in Miami. But, it was passable enough for our culinary taste on this particular afternoon.  I ordered the Lechon Asado. Along with it, I had to have the Flan. My friends ordered the deep fried chicken, and the Cuban Sandwich.  Cubans love their pork, and no meal would be complete without at least some type of roast pork. This lunch hour was no different. The pork was tender, flavorful, and well seasoned. A little on the bland side for my taste, but it was passable enough. The accompanying Arroz Congri (Cuban Black beans and Rice) was quite tasty, and did much to enhance the meal. I wasn't too enamored with the overly greasy onions. Nor were the vegetables all that fresh. All-in-all, the meal was very satisfying and scrumptious.  According to one of my friends, the Cuban Sandwich, which was a combination of ham and cheese, wasn't really that appealing. It was very dry, and the ham tasted as if it was processed.   And my other friend, who just came back from a trip to Cuba, wasn't all that enamored with the Deep Fried Chicken. Although, he did indicate that the skin was quite crispy and spicily flavored. He mentioned didn't taste that fresh.   Of course, my flan was absolutely scrumptious. It was rich, somewhat sweet, and was appropriate layering to give it that caramel flavor.  Although we weren't in any hurry whatsoever, it wound up being a 2 1/2 hour lunch engagement. This was due to the fact that the place was packed, and there was only one server. And as diligent as she was, it was difficult for her to handle all those customers, along with the takeout orders and the bakery customers. Getting our check was a monumental task.  In spite of the hiccups, and my friends' fastidiousness regarding food tastes and quality; I would still recommend this place. Just don't be in any hurry when you dine here, during their busy times.

I have been to Miami a bunch and on a scale of 1-10 on the Cuban sandwich I would give it a 10 for authenticity, but a 7 for flavor. The ham was a little dry. The mustard was not too aromatic, the bread was nice but it could have used some more planchette and butter time.

The croquettes I was really not a big fan of, not sure what they were made of but they didn't taste like ham. Yuca was ok especially with the garlic sauce that came with it.   We ordered two main dishes to try Ropa Vieja and the Cuban Sandwich. Ok the sandwich is really a good size sandwich but that's about it. It wasn't pressed, the cheese was not melted and there was very little pork inside. The ropa vieja neither my sister or I enjoyed this much, she kept the taste of it all night though lol.  Staff was friendly but I highly doubt we would make a return visit.

JTEwot6F9qnvF0VDLLXHqA.text: Astonishing.   The food here is unbelievably good, very authentic, home made and fresh. ul16h2mPwX0os_43sp1zNw.text: Well, I'm a Cuban guy who grew up in Miami. I am currently living in Northern Nevada and in the process of moving to Phoenix. In Northern Nevada, there is not a lot of diversity. This could be due the proximity to Lake Tahoe, and the abundance of snow during the winter. I miss, miss, miss, Cuban Food and nothing is more frustrating when people don't get it. I vent to friends how I miss the food and how lazy I am not learn how to cook it...and all they say is "dude, go to pepito's tacoria" NOOOOO DUDE, IT'S NOT THE SAME. MEXICAN FOOD AND CUBAN FOOD IS DIFFERENT! They don't know better.    I found this place, and I was hesitant. I went to a Cuban Restaurant in San Francisco, it was NOT Cuban food. The west coast had not treated me well in this area. When I arrived to the restaurant, I noticed it was a little hole in the wall near a DJ store and a Metro PCS. I immediately got excited; because, unless your going to Versailles, Cuban food is not fancy.    I ordered the bistec empanizado. I loved it. The portions were large, how it should be, and the steak was good. I was impressed. My girlfriend had the medianoche, and she liked it. She is a Northern Nevada blonde white girl, so I gauged her and asked "is it Latin America good?" Latin America being a prominent cuban sandwich place in Miami. She said that it was just as good.    Impressive.   The business looks like it is somewhat new and just now getting clientele. I hope it does well. I love seeing my paisanos succeed. Get that money papo!   But PLEASE, get a bathroom, really? No bathroom...conjone meng   I am typing this on my phone, sorry for any grammar errors...

UYeX3EgUD3gWeAJDLoPyzg.text: Tucked away in the strip mall, this small Cuban bakery has been overlooked and undervalued by many who don't frequent the area or knows very little about the cuisine. Once inside, there are only six small tables. The red tablecloths, glass dessert counter, tiled floors, and bright natural lighting coming through the doors nicely accentuated the decor. Fellow Yelper Kurdy S and I were the only non-Spanish speaking customers during this afternoon. Like many of the nearby restaurants, the atmosphere was fitting as a casual lunch spot.  For appetizer, we shared the Tostones Rellenos de Roja Villeja ($4.49). The plate came with four fried green plantains holding a small scoop of tender shredded beef on top. The plantains had great texture on the outside to add to the soft green banana flavor on the inside. The beef was tender, flavorful, complex, and very nicely seasoned. I can eat these all day long.  We also had a side order of Plantanos Maduro Fritos ($2.49) that came with soft bananas served piping hot, perfectly fried, and sweet. It was nicely glazed, but also unexpectedly oily.   Next, the Cuban Sandwich ($6.95) came with shredded beef, ham, and mustard. The bread had an awesome crunch with an excellent secondary chew. The sandwich was big enough to share and the dish also came with French fries. The way they kept it simple without all the fillers made this one of the best Cuban Sandwiches I've had so far.  Finally, the Filete a la Plancha ($9.99) came with a big serving of grilled sole, black bean rice, and salad. The sole was fresh, moist, tender, and had good flavor but slightly over salted. The black bean rice had great flavor and moisture--much better than the one at Victor's 1959 Cafe. The lightly dressed salad provided a nice change of pace to the sole.  Antithetical to the cuisine's longstanding stereotype of being bland, this place simply rocks. Service however, was friendly but also inattentive, offbeat, and at times awkward. For instance, the food and bill took forever to come, and our water was never refilled even though the restaurant was not busy. Despite the shortcomings, interested diners should still come for the impressive lineup of dishes and great prices. I'd be very interested in coming back to try their other seafood and chicken items followed by their great looking desserts.

nkmuE8Ocx9JzX3I4rXipAQ.text: Like most Americans, I've never been to Cuba in my lifetime.  And until recently I never suspected I would.  But like many Americans I've always had at least a passing curiosity about our neighbors just 90 miles south of the Keys.  Cuban culture (as with many cultures) has been quietly influencing American life in subtle but noticeable ways from music, to the classic car movement, and yes even the culinary arts as well.  Admittedly living here in Arizona means we don't encounter much in the way of Cuban influence, much less Cuban cuisine.  Havana Cafe was widely regarded as the Cuban culinary staple of the valley for many years.  Sadly, Havana Cafe closed its doors earlier this year before I had a chance to take in the experience.  That leaves maybe 3 Cuban restaurants left in the valley that I'm aware of.  And the only one in the city of Phoenix is Cuban Foods Bakery.  I came here for lunch on a Thursday to try and finally get a taste of what so many chefs and food critics were raving about when it came to traditional Cuban cuisine.  In the end, I arrived a novice and left wanting to do the cha-cha.  Located in a strip mall on the northeast corner of Peoria and 43rd Ave, Cuban Foods reminds me a great deal of the setup of the recently defunct Latin American haven Mi Comida.  A simple table and chairs place with a few native emblems on the wall, but little else in the way of aesthetics.  There's Cuban music playing in the background to lighten the mood and the placemats are a bounty of color for the senses.  I got here right at 11am and was their first customer of the day, but the place filled up for lunch shortly thereafter.  I counted 6 tables with 4 chairs at each so room for 24 here max.  There was just one waitress on duty and she was delightfully friendly and helpful.  I knew some of what I was getting for lunch, but she helped me with the rest.  I decided to start with a menu item that enticed me right away.  The Tostones Camarones.  Four green plantains made into little bowls and fried, then stuffed with shrimp covered in garlic sauce.  Wow, wow, wow.  This is an appetizer that eats like a meal as the cups were each packed full of shrimps (at least a dozen in each cup) and the texture of the bowsl were soft on the inside with a nice crunch on the outside that absorbed the juices beautifully.  Still craving more authentic Cuban cuisine, I went with the standard Cubano sandwich (note: they discount the sandwich at lunch and include a free choice of canned soda, of which I chose an orange Fanta).  Roasted pork, ham, pickles, Swiss cheese, and mustard on Cuban bread.  If i had to describe the bread it would almost be like a kaiser roll in panini form.  Unlike most panini sandwiches, the interior of the bread maintains its chewy texture while the outside retains the crunchy notes.  I can see why the Cubano is a staple of most every Cuban establishment.  Fantastic meat flavors densely packed together with the condiments.  And surprisingly it didn't taste as heavy as I expected.  Despite already being full, this is Cuban Foods "Bakery" after all and the bakery display case was packed full of tasty looking desserts to try.  I asked the waitress for suggestions and after some back and forth, we settled on a dessert that almost acts as two desserts in one.  A slice of their Tocinillo del Cielo.  While this dish literally translates as "Bacon from Heaven", there's no actual bacon in it (though using bacon as a description is always endearing in my book).  There's two layers to this version.  The bottom layer is a moist white sponge cake while the top layer is a flan-like pudding.  A deliciously smooth, creamy and surprisingly light dessert.  Every dish I had was so phenomenal I could basically care less about how crazy full I was.  Total cost for all the food, plus the soda, tax, and tip came to $23.  Great prices for the amount of food you get here.  I'll be back in the near future to dive further into more delicious Cuban cuisine.  Its a shame its so rare to find a Cuban spot here in Phoenix for a cuisine that's so widely respected.  Hopefully as relations thaw between our two countries and there's a more open sharing of cultures and traditions, we'll see an even greater influx of Cuban treasures into Arizona and beyond.

HvBdun8ozDQdqvyo_7Xb2A.text: I'm a born and raised in Miami Cuban and this place has the most authentic Cuban food I've had outside of Miami. The service can be a bit slow but the food can't be beat.

jHIMla6F26LP0AAMzwcXJg.text: This is a cozy place perfect for a nice lunch! There is one server and one cook...take your patience with you but it is worth the wait.   The Cuban sandwich is the best 7 dollars I have spent in a long time...the pulled pork gave that sandwich an amazing flavor. The food was hot and delightful, they also are a bakery and the cheesecake is very good to be honest it's about as good as Cheesecake Factory's!   The authenticity of this place is what I truly loved the Cuban coffee that they freshly brew! With Cuban roots in my family this was a piece of heritage I will revisit.  If you have kids make sure they use the restroom before you go because this place doesn't have a restroom...but one can always walk across the parking lot to Jack in the Box and use the restroom...

IFKsbXjdKd0_70Tsaa1bqw.text: Horrible food, horrible service! We found  a hair in the rice!  And the owner would not even discount the dinner after we sent it back.  They are understaffed, and who does work there can't even speak or understand English! If your looking for True Cuban food I would PASS on this dump!!!!!! Dirty too no hand soap in the bathrooms so how are the workers washing there hands after they go to the restroom?!  I wish I could give this a Minus star, doesn't deserve a forth of one!

2b2P-hh3a5THzv3KlPC-wQ.text: If you've never tried Cuban food, this is where to start. This place is dynamite. We love the sandwiches, they are all amazing. And the desserts - wow! Tip when you go - skip the fries as the side for your sandwich and get the rice and beans.

NFpUGWhJ-bQYWZ27nl0WZg.text: Living in Tucson, Cuban food is nonexistent. Any time I'm traveling through Phoenix I try and make a stop at some type of Cuban restaurant. This one has become my favorite. It's located in a strip mall so don't let that discourage you, you will not be disappointed! I usually go for the beef bistec empanizado which comes with moro style black beans and rice. The portion size is huge! Definitely shareable if you're not too hungry. I've also tried the papa rellenas and croquetas de jamon which are delicious! Small little place but the food is awesome!

_IFfYHKaGPTAdpOMzb__OQ.text: We decided to try this place out based on the great reviews on Yelp. Upon entering, we were greeted immediately as we walked in and were handed menus as we sat. Despite our group of three being the only ones in the restaurant, it was about 10 minutes before the lady came back to take our order. I ordered the Sandwich Cubano, my hubby ordered the Ropa Vieja, and we also ordered the empanadas. It was about 20 minutes after ordering that our food finally came out of the kitchen.   My sandwich was good. The bread was thin and crispy, and the pickles added a good bit of saltiness and crunch, but it was a little on the dry side and probably could have used a little more meat. The Ropa Vieja was very good. The meat was tender and flavorful, and the mole sauce had a nice smoky flavor. The empanadas, which were listed in the Appetizers section of the menu yet were the last plate to come out, were okay. They were a bit dry since it had a lot more breading than meat.   Overall, the food was decent but the service was a bit slow. We came for lunch during work and probably won't again as it took so long. Their pastries, however, looked good in the display case, so maybe we'll come back to try those.
